awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  New World Justicia s.l.:   A microcosm for understanding covariation of floral traits and pollinators in a phylogenetic context
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how flowering plants interact with animal pollinators over evolutionary time. Flowering plants dominate the majority of terrestrial ecosystems and most depend on animal pollinators to complete their lifecycle. Biologists hypothesize that the interaction with pollinators ultimately increases the number of flowering plants over time. However, important details are lacking about how this might be happening. Flower color, shape, and size are widely understood to reflect adaptation to pollinators. Yet, emerging evidence indicates that microscopic changes in floral features may also have large effects in driving new species to evolve. This project will investigate how biochemical, microscopic and macroscopic traits of flowers vary with different animal pollinators in the water-willow genus, Justicia. Researchers will determine the evolutionary relationships among Justicia species native to North, Central and South America to analyze trait data, including field-based observations of pollinator behavior. The project will train high school, undergraduate and graduate students, including members of under-represented groups and community college students, as well as a post-doctoral research associate. Researchers will provide outreach to the public about the ecological and economic importance of pollination biology through educational exhibits at the University of Colorado Boulder Museum of Natural History and Rancho Santa Ana Botanical Garden.

This project will test the hypothesis that variation in morphological traits intimately involved with the reproductive success of flowering plants are inter-correlated and are associated with functional groups of animal visitors. Researchers will investigate the evolutionary history of New World Justicia (Acanthaceae; the Acanthus family), whose ca. 400 species show remarkable diversity in micro-morphological floral traits essential to reproduction, including anthers, pollen and stigmas, and support a range of vertebrate and invertebrate pollinators. Outcomes of the research will include a comprehensive phylogenetic hypothesis for New World Justicia species based on nuclear genomic data, a quantitative analysis of macro- and micro-morphological variation in relationship to pollinator type, and improved taxonomic circumscriptions for this widespread yet poorly characterized lineage. Research will facilitate the discovery and description of species new to science, build herbarium research collections, and expand ethological information about pollinating animals. Targeted fieldwork in five Neotropical countries will strengthen international collaborations among US and Latin American scientists and facilitate investigation of this species-rich lineage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Animal pollinators fertilize over 80 of the world’s most important food crops by bringing pollen to their flowers to produce fruits and seeds. Some of the crops that rely on pollinators are almond, apple, avocado, and canola. To effectively fertilize a flower, a pollinator must transfer pollen from one flower to another and many plants have evolved characteristics to attract pollinators and ensure transfer of the pollen. Differences in flower petal colors and shapes have been the focus of many previous studies on pollination and petals are often associated with attracting pollinators such as hummingbirds, bees, or butterflies. This process of adaptation to specific pollinator types can result in similar petal shapes and colors in flowers that are pollinated by the same pollinator group. 

Although pollen transfer is essential for fertilization, little is known about adaptation of pollen to pollinators. We studied the pollen and seed producing organs of flowers to test how they adapt to different groups of pollinators. To do this we studied American species in the genus Justicia (Acanthaceae) that are adapted to bee, butterfly, hummingbird, fly, wasp, and other pollinators. Justicia is especially useful for this kind of study because of the variety of pollinators that are used by closely related species. PI Fisher and students from California State University, Long Beach did field work in Brazil, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Mexico, and the United States to collect 89 new museum specimens to study their flowers. We spent hours in the field studying which animals may be pollinating the flowers of 34 different species of Justicia, exceeding our goals for this objective of the project. We used powerful microscopes to image the flower organs and found differences in their sizes and shapes. The most important differences we have found so far are in pollen organ position and pollen shape. We have worked with our collaborators to contribute to sequencing the DNA of over half of the Justicia species in the Americas so we can understand how the species are related to each other. We shared these results at scientific meetings, regional meetings, and University symposia and through peer-reviewed papers, posters, and theses. Scientists can use these findings to document plant diversity, improve the classification of Justicia, and study how the mutualism between animals and flowers evolves and can lead to changes in flowers.    

During the project 15 California State University, Long Beach students worked on the project, including participation in field work and molecular laboratory skills. Students learned how to analyze data and present it through presentations and theses. These skills have translated to employment for some of these students in ecological consulting and pharmaceutical manufacturing.
